data.title: Good News: Political group hands out 'Gutsy Woman Award.' Event honors life of Anne Braden
data.meta_description: Political Women's Council honors Dolores Delahanty. Celebration planned for Louisville civil rights icon
data.text:
In a world full of political strife, poverty and violence, we are constantly bombarded with bad news. Yes, it is the job of media outlets like us to inform people about the mayhem.

Yet, it's also important to shine a light on the good things happening in the communities on both sides of the Ohio River in Kentuckiana.

This weekly column will highlight some of those people and their accomplishments. We hope you will read it routinely and tell us what we’re missing.

This week's good news is all about the women — strong women of vision and purpose who have helped pave the way for many. We honor them.

Political group honors feminist icon

Dolores Delahanty is one gutsy woman. And she's got an award to prove it.

The Political Women's Council on Monday gave the longtime social activist and political leader its inaugural "Gutsy Woman Award," which will now be known as "The Dolores."

Mayor Greg Fischer also proclaimed Monday as Dolores Delahanty Day.

Delahanty has devoted her life to improving the lives of others, primarily those of Kentucky women and children. She was the president of the Kentucky chapter of the National Association of Social Workers and later vice president of the national group.

Delahanty was given a crystal clock to represent her accomplishments. The event, which was part of a yearlong commemoration of the 19th Amendment. Former Lt. Gov. Crit Luallen spoke about the women's suffrage movement.

More than 100 people gathered to celebrate Delahanty, who has a long list of accomplishments. She served on the Kentucky Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. In a 1978 report, the committee presented evidence showing that neither race nor gender were properly represented within the Kentucky Police Force. She led a challenge to the credentials of the Kentucky democratic delegation to the 1972 national convention in Miami. After that challenge, all delegations to the Democratic National Conventions were to be 50% female.

From 1973 to 1976, Delahanty was the secretary of the Kentucky Governor's Commission on Women. Instrumental in the passage of Kentucky's Fair Credit Law, Delahanty was appointed by President Jimmy Carter to study the aid given to women from the Cabinet of Health and Human Services.

Delahanty was inducted into the Kentucky Civil Rights Hall of Fame in 2012, and her portrait hangs in the West Wing of the state Capitol as part of the Kentucky Women Remembered exhibit.

Anne Braden commemoration planned

Anne McCarty Braden was a writer, a civil rights activist and a warrior in the battle to end state-sponsored segregation. An event to celebrate her life and work is set for noon Saturday, March 7, at St. George’s Episcopal Church, where Braden was a member.

Braden spent much of her life fighting for racial equity and civil rights. People who worked and worshiped alongside her will speak at the commemoration, and numerous exhibits will focus on her time at St. George’s.

Braden and her husband, Carl Braden, gained national attention in 1954 when they bought a house for an African American couple in an all-white neighborhood near Shively. The house was bombed in response, but no one was hurt. The couple were charged with sedition and accused of planning the explosion to stir up trouble and promote communism. The Bradens denied the charges.

Carl's eventual conviction was later overturned, and he was released from jail.

After Carl died in 1975, Anne went on to support many causes, including busing to desegregate Jefferson County's public schools. She also spoke out on issues such as gay rights, Rubbertown pollution and police shootings of black residents. She was arrested numerous times.

After turning 80, Braden continued to organize protests and show up at local government meetings. She died in 2006 at age 81.

Her work for social and economic justice was recognized by The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in his famous 1963 "Letter from a Birmingham Jail." He expressed his gratitude to a group of white Southerners, including Braden, who “have written about our struggle in eloquent and prophetic terms... and committed themselves to it.”

People attending the commemoration at St. George's Church, 1201 S. 26th St., are asked to bring a non-perishable food item for the church’s Dare to Care food distribution site.

A daughter of greatness to speak

Victoria Russell, the first chief of diversity, equity and inclusion at Papa John’s International, will speak Friday at the Daughters of Greatness breakfast at the Muhammad Ali Center.

Russell has called her job the most challenging she's had in her career and says she is committed to using her voice to bring about change.

The Daughters of Greatness breakfast series honors prominent women engaged in social change, activism and pursuits of justice. Your ticket to the event includes a hot breakfast served at 8:30 a.m. followed by the program from 9 to 10 a.m. Tickets are available online. Or contact Morgan Szabo at 502-992-5312.
